close_symbols: type of r_iov->iov elements (e.g. struct iovec on POSIX or WSABUF/LPWSABUF on Windows)
explanation:
- HAVE_SENDMSG: Determines whether the memset(&msg, 0, sizeof(struct msghdr)) call is present in the compiled code path. You must know if this branch is compiled to analyze any string.h usage.  
- struct msghdr: The memset target and size are &msg and sizeof(struct msghdr). The definition (layout/size) is required to confirm that memset writes exactly the bounds of the local object (no flexible array / hidden overrun issues).  
- pre_send_setopt: Called before sendmsg/writev/WSASend. Its implementation could call string.h functions on buffers/fields accessible from this function (connection, iov structures). Include it to detect any indirect string.h usage that might operate on objects passed or shared with send_iov_nontls.  
- post_send_setopt: Called after the final iov element is consumed; its implementation may call string.h functions (via MHD_DLOG or otherwise) that operate on buffers from this function. Include it for the same reason as pre_send_setopt.  
- struct MHD_iovec_track_: Definition is required to understand r_iov->cnt, r_iov->sent, and the iov array length/contents. These fields govern indexing into r_iov->iov and are needed to confirm that any memset/memcpy/memmove (direct or indirect) would not access beyond the iov array bounds.  
- type of r_iov->iov elements (e.g. struct iovec on POSIX or WSABUF/LPWSABUF on Windows): The code reads and adjusts iov[r_iov->sent].iov_len and iov_base. If any string.h calls are applied to these buffers (directly here or in callee functions), you must know the element layout and semantics (buffer pointer, length) to decide whether those calls can stray out-of-bounds.  
- _MHD_IOV_MAX: Controls truncation of items_to_send and sets push_data=false in that branch. It affects msg.msg_iovlen / writev count and therefore whether msg.msg_iovlen might exceed the actual available iov elements; include to validate that the number of iov entries passed to the kernel never exceeds the actual array bounds.  
- MHD_iov_size_ typedef: Used when decrementing iov_len (r_iov->iov[r_iov->sent].iov_len -= (MHD_iov_size_) track_sent). The exact type/width matters for correctness of pointer/length arithmetic and to ensure no wrap/underflow that could cause subsequent string.h calls to operate out-of-bounds.  
- mhd_assert macro: Assertions in the function (e.g. mhd_assert ((r_iov->cnt > r_iov->sent) || (0 == track_sent))) are used to document invariants that prevent out-of-bounds indexing. You must know whether mhd_assert is active or compiled out (and whether the code relies on it defensively) to assess safety with respect to the MISRA rule.
